div1.p: I have seen Mr. Chaffee, and next Sunday Bower is going with me to talk with him again. He is a delightful person with a wonderful twinkle of humor in his face and in his words. He doesn't hear well, and wears an aid, but he has no apparent physical difficulty as a result of the stroke. He doesn't use his arm much, but he seems to get around well. He has less energy than you have, but that's true of everyone I know. He is making a note of everything he remembers, and will tell me all of it when I go back. I do wish the two of you could get together!

If you still have Mr. Chaffee's letters, please don't destroy them. When you have finished with them I would like to see them if they have reminiscences in them. Anything like that should be saved for permanent record.

Mrs. Skillings is a lovely person. She has a very sweet face and an inner poise of manner that the strong, giving people have. Her husband is an invalid, confined to a bed, but he is alert and interested in all sorts of things. He lent me a copy of Sunshine Magazine
53
that has an article about Custer's battle. They are all very much interested in you, and enjoyed the pictures of you that I took over to show them.

There are some minor news items, but they're interesting: I took the tapes over to the library to listen to them, and as I sat in the audio-visual room, passers-by became quite excited and stopped to ask questions. Martin Schmitt, the Historical Society man, came down to listen and wants to use some of the Jed Smith tape in the T.V. show I told you about. It's in April, and I have promised to help with it — but why should I read Jed Smith passages when people can hear you read them? The only problem is that I don't know what legal complications could result from use of the tapes. Do you know the copyright deal on such things? Can the tape of you reading Jed be used on a program about you on TV? I suppose tape recordings and TV programs complicate the copyright laws terribly, and I would appreciate any information you have on the matter.

Mr. Kelly writes that a little town in Montana is named Neihardt, and he thinks it's for you. I'm writing the postmaster to try to get the story in writing for the record. Do you know anything about it?

I now have a complete copy of "Song of the Hoe" — I copied it out of The Youth's Companion, and I see why now. Mr. Long was impressed with it. It's a good poem; you
54
had a genius for rhythm from the very beginning I shall now hunt up the "Skating Song."

I'm well along with the second chapter, which is lots of fun to write; it's about your theory of rhetoric and how it grew. I was surprised how clean your taste in speech was when I got the Blade comments together form the year you edited. Did you ever hear T.R. speak in person? You wrote about his speaking several times, but I had the impression your reactions were from reading the speeches and reading about them. You never liked the ornate style, I was happy to see. Reading about you is quite exciting — you could have gone so many directions and arrived at the top, and all the time, as you have said yourself, the real point was the living. More than one person has said to me, "It must be wonderful to write about a man like that!" and it is.

I suspect you're all getting ready for the spring horse shows. I shall be thinking about you, and I will want to see all the blue ribbons in June. Give everyone my love, please, and I'll write again after we're back to Albany.

postscript.p: I haven't forgotten the General Crook book. It is out of print and Mr. Schmitt is trying to find you a copy — for me to send you I mean.
